732928f.title: Social conditions - [Interior of a two-room apartment.]
732928f.text:
Social Conditions in Manhattan: In this 2 room apartment at No.
263 Stanton Street, live a father, a mother, two children and a boarder--
5 in all. The foreground is the kitchen, living and dining room in the
day time which at night becomes a "Pullman car;" two folding cots being
stretched out. Vndoubtedly published by the New York Evening World of
this date.
November 27, 1923.
Gift of New Yorl World.
N.g.~ 2472
2N ~10

720300f-a.title: Manhattan: Pitt Street - Stanton Street
720300f-a.text:
Hamilton Fish Park: An eastward view of the southern portion of
same, as viewed from Pitt (foreground) at Stanton (right) Streets. P.S.
No. 22, which appears across the Park, is at the N.E. corner of Stanton
and Sheriff Streets.
June 26, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
720300f-a.folder: Pitt Street & Stanton Street, Manhattan, NY

720299f-a.title: Manhattan: Pitt Street - Stanton Street
720299f-a.folder: Pitt Street & Stanton Street, Manhattan, NY

720301f.title: Manhattan: Pitt Street - Stanton Street
720301f.text:
Hamilton Fish Park: The northern half of same, containing the
recently constructed (by the W.P.A.) swimming pool. The view is
westward to Pitt Street (center background) between Stanton (left) and
East Houston (right) Streets. Photographers vantage point is on Willet.
Street, which divides this open play area into two equal halves.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
V EE77
720301f.folder: Pitt Street & Stanton Street, Manhattan, NY
